Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Syntactic Ergativity in West Circassian

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A central question in linguistic research on the structure of sentences is how to identify the subject of a sentence, and whether this can be done in a uniform way for all languages. In many languages (e.g. English and Japanese), the subject can be identified as the most prominent element in a sentence, according to many grammatical phenomena. However, so-called ergative languages present a puzzle to this relatively stable cross-linguistic picture, since in these languages, the object, rather than the subject, behaves as the most prominent element according to some of those same phenomena. Two broad approaches have been taken in dealing with ergative languages. The first consists in claiming that ergativity is a surface phenomenon; that is, it is not a reflection of deep structural differences between ergative and nonergative languages. The second approach claims that ergative languages are in fact structurally different from nonergative languages, in that the subject is not always the most prominent element in the sentence. Settling this debate will be an important step towards gaining a better understanding of the range of possible variation in the structure of human languages.

An important step in addressing this debate is the close investigation of languages that have been claimed to be ergative, since many of them remain relatively understudied. The present project focuses on one such language: West Circassian, of the Northwest Caucasian family. Based on previous descriptions of the language, the PI and co-PI adopt the second approach described above as their initial hypothesis in accounting for ergativity in this language. In order to test this hypothesis, the co-PI will work with native speakers of West Circassian in the Republic of Adygea, Russia. The data to be collected will primarily comprise recorded conversations with speakers and oral narratives. Whether the hypothesis is confirmed or not, the project will present a valuable contribution to our understanding of the limits of linguistic variation, as well as to our knowledge of currently understudied aspects of West Circassian.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has supported research into several previously understudied aspects of West Circassian, an ergative polysynthetic language that has not received sufficient attention in the literature. The major outcome of this project, which culminated in the publication of Ksenia Ershova’s dissertation, has been providing evidence for a nuanced picture of subjecthood and the organization of event participants more generally. The collected data provides systematic evidence for a decomposed understanding of subjecthood: in an ergative language like West Circassian, there may be two distinct arguments which display subjecthood properties, and the distribution of these properties is predictable based on well-understood grammatical constraints which are observed in better-studied languages. This project provides an in-depth analysis of several grammatical domains of West Circassian: the behavior of reflexives and reciprocals, parasitic gap constructions, and control configurations, presenting these constructions in a theoretically familiar light and explaining their apparent peculiarities in a systematic fashion. In terms of a broader theoretical impact, the project provides support for the view that a theory of grammar must accommodate the possibility of several subjects in a single sentence, and puts into question the viability and usefulness of subjecthood as a theoretical primitive.  

In addition to the dissertation, the results of this project have been presented at several conference venues, a portion of the project is in print for publication in the peer-reviewed journal Linguistic Inquiry, and another portion has been submitted as a manuscript for peer-review. As a result of this research, the linguistic community has a much better understanding of the West Circassian grammar and the role it might play in the broader theoretical landscape.

The project focuses on a vulnerable minority language: West Circassian is spoken in Russia, and even in the Republic of Adygea where West Circassian is one of the official languages, most everyday interactions are conducted in Russian. This grant has made possible the documentation of the grammar of a language that is at the ongoing risk of rapid shift to the majority language – Russian. This grant has encouraged a growing academic interest in West Circassian and the collection and publication of new data, which may prove to be an asset to future generations of linguistics, as well as for the West Circassian community.
